Description: Ivory clapper; one end carved in the form of an animal-head; incised detail filled with black on ear, eye and collar; tip of ear, muzzle and back end broken off. Reverse side undecorated, flat.
Curator's comments: For parallels see Hickmann, H., 1949. Catalogue General des antiquités égyptiennes du Musée du Caire: Instruments de musique. (Cairo: l'Institut français d'archéologie oriental); pl. xiv, xv; Saad, Z. Y., 1947. Royal excavations at Saqqara and Helwan (1941-1945) (Cairo: l'Institut français d'archéologie orientale), pl.xiii. The identity of the animal depicted is unclear, but it is often considered a rabbit or hare. It is the most frequently occurring head on clappers of First Dynasty date.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Sir Charles Holled Smith
